block.p: Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Fiction
TEARS OF THE MOON, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) An Irish songwriter, shut off from the world, finds hope and happiness with a tomboy.
THE POISONWOOD BIBLE, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.) Five female characters narrate a novel set in the Belgian Congo during the fight for independence.
WHILE I WAS GONE, by Sue Miller. (Ballantine, $12.95.) The wife of a minister begins a flirtation.
ASHES TO ASHES, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $7.99.) Kate Conlan, a former F.B.I. agent, tracks a serial killer in Minneapolis.
HANNIBAL, by Thomas Harris. (Dell, $7.99.) Hannibal Lecter is still at large.
TOM CLANCY'S OP-CENTER: Divide and Conquer, created by Tom Clancy and Steve Pieczenik; written by Jeff Rovin. (Berkley, $7.99.) Traitors try to oust the president.
IRISH HEARTS, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $7.50.) Two previously published novels, now in one volume, about Irishwomen's lives in America.
LIGHTNING STRIKES, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket Star, $7.99.) A drama student goes to live with her great-aunt, whose estate is filled with terrors.
ACTS OF MALICE, by Perri O'Shaughnessy. (Island, $7.50.) Nina Reilly defends a man accused of murdering his brother.
IRISH REBEL, by Nora Roberts. (Silhouette, $4.50.) The latest novel in a series about Irish families in America.
ECLIPSE BAY, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Jove, $7.50.) A man and a woman, whose Oregon families are engaged in a longtime feud, fall in love.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling. (Scholastic, $5.99.) A British boy attends a school for witchcraft.
THE SAVING GRACES, by Patricia Gaffney. (HarperTorch, $6.99.) The close friendship that binds four women is put to the test.
ROBERT LUDLUM'S THE HADES FACTOR, by Robert Ludlum and Gayle Lynds. (St. Martin's Griffin, $15.95.) Fighting a doomsday virus.
THE GIRLS' GUIDE TO HUNTING AND FISHING, by Melissa Bank. (Penguin, $12.95.) The love life of a young New York woman.
*FROM THE HEART, by Nora Roberts. (Berkley, $14.95.) Three novels about torrid love affairs.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Nonfiction
THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14; HarperPaperbacks, $6.99.) The northeaster of 1991.
THE SEAT OF THE SOUL, by Gary Zukav. (Fireside/S&S, $12.) How daily activities can be enhanced by feelings of meaning and purpose. (+)
THE HUNGRY OCEAN, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $14.) A sea captain's account of her 30-day swordfishing voyage off the Northeast coast.
GIRL, INTERRUPTED, by Susanna Kaysen. (Vintage, $12.) A young woman's mental illness.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
*ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Touchstone/S&S, $14 and $7.99.) An Irish-American writer recalls his childhood in Limerick.
*A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $13.) Hiking the Appalachian Trail.
I'M A STRANGER HERE MYSELF, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $14.) What it's like to return to the United States after living abroad.
*THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Anchor, $15.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
*THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' ''recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
THE ELEGANT UNIVERSE, by Brian Greene. (Vintage, $15.) A physicist's presentation of superstring theory.
*THE FIRST WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Vintage, $16.) A military historian recounts the 1914-18 conflict.
*GUNS, GERMS, AND STEEl, by Jared Diamond. (Norton, $14.95.) A physiologist attributes Western dominance to geography. (+)
*EVERY MAN A TIGER, by Tom Clancy with Chuck Horner. (Berkley, $16.95.) The novelist and a retired Air Force general examine the gulf war.
TRAVELING MERCIES, by Anne Lamott. (Anchor, $13.) A chronicle of the author's journey toward faith and spirituality.
*I AIN'T GOT TIME TO BLEED, by Jesse Ventura. (Signet, $6.99.) Reflections on politics, professional wrestling and other subjects by the governor of Minnesota.
Weeks
This
On
Week
List
Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous
TAKE TIME FOR YOUR LIFE, by Cheryl Richardson. (Broadway, $13.) A seven-step program for enhancing one's social, financial and spiritual well-being. (+)
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Avon, $14 and $6.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
CHICKEN SOUP FOR THE TEENAGE SOUL III, compiled by Jack Canfield, Mark Victor Hansen and Kimberly Kirberger. (Health Communications, $12.95.) Inspirational stories. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending July 1, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some stores received bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.
